source.raw_text:
The Sandbag Clean is a total-body power movement working legs (quads, hamstrings, glutes), back (lats, traps, erectors), core (obliques, abs), shoulders (deltoids), arms, and grip, involving a hip-driven, explosive pull from the floor to the shoulders, mimicking real-life lifting, challenging stability, and building functional strength. Key patterns include the Deadlift pull, explosive Hip Extension, and dynamic Catch, requiring coordination, core bracing, and grip strength due to the unstable weight. [1, 2, 3]  
Muscles Worked 

• Legs: Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes (powering the initial lift). 
• Back: Traps, Lats, Erector Spinae (stabilizing and assisting the pull). 
• Core: Obliques, Abdominals (crucial for stability and transferring force). 
• Shoulders & Arms: Deltoids, Biceps, Forearms (catching and controlling the bag). 
• Grip: Forearms and hands (essential for holding the awkward, shifting load). [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Patterns 

1. Deadlift/Pull: Starting from the floor in a hip-hinge position, pulling the bag up your legs. 
2. Explosive Hip Drive: A powerful, rapid extension of the hips and knees to generate upward momentum. 
3. Scoop/Catch: Quickly pulling your elbows forward and rotating under the bag to catch it in the "front rack" position (resting on forearms/biceps). 
4. Front Squat Transition (Optional): Dropping into a front squat to receive the bag before standing up. 
5. Stabilization: Constant core bracing and activation to manage the shifting weight and maintain posture. [1, 2, 3, 4, 8]  

Key Aspects 

• Total-Body Power: Develops explosive strength and coordination. 
• Functional Fitness: Mimics lifting awkward objects. 
• Core & Stabilizers: The unstable load heavily taxes the core and smaller stabilizing muscles. 
• Grip Strength: A major benefit due to the lack of fixed handles. [1, 2, 4]  

**Citations:**
